lucasb-eyer,pydensecrf,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/98,521452987,MDU6SXNzdWU1MjE0NTI5ODc=,98,Segmentation faults for small `srgb`,629706,open,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2019-11-12T10:12:23Z,2019-11-12T10:12:23Z,NA,NONE,NA,First of all, thanks a lot for packaging this!
I've noticed some interesting errors when creating a pairwise potential with very small stddev for the feature comparison. Minimal example:
When passing a small scale parameter (1e-8 and smaller), I can provoke different crashes:
The error message is not completely deterministic.
Relevant part of the backtrace for one of those:

So in this case, it crashed at https://github.com/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/blob/0632813/pydensecrf/densecrf/src/permutohedral.cpp#L283, I also get crashes at line 255 or 284. All this seems like some memory is overwritten somewhere.
Running `valgrind --tool=memcheck --suppressions=valgrind-python.supp python3 crfbug.py 64 1e-8`, the first two relevant errors are:
==30527==  Address 0x140b7c58 is 8 bytes before a block of size 32 alloc'd
==30696==  Address 0x140b7c28 is 8 bytes after a block of size 80 alloc'd

Focusing on the latter, in https://github.com/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/blob/0632813/pydensecrf/densecrf/src/permutohedral.cpp#L255, it's writing beyond the array allocated in https://github.com/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/blob/0632813/pydensecrf/densecrf/src/permutohedral.cpp#L160, which is the `barycentric` array. So `barycentric[j*(d_+2)+p  ]` seems to be used with a too large index. This probably means that the `rank` array contained negative values?

Anyway, that's all I can do quickly without delving into the algorithm and/or compiling the package myself. And I realize this is outside the scope of the Python wrapper, so you may not want to deal with this, but maybe at least it will help someone searching for this error.",NA,FALSE,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/98/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/98/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/98/events,https://github.com/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/98,NA

lucasb-eyer,pydensecrf,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/14,154082378,MDU6SXNzdWUxNTQwODIzNzg=,14,buf2matf makes a copy of the feature map,2582408,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,3,2016-05-10T19:05:11Z,2016-05-12T01:15:11Z,2016-05-11T18:09:14Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,In the experiments I'm currently running, the setup (call to addPairwiseEnergy) takes nearly as long as the inference itself. ,NA,TRUE,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/6/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/6/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/6/events,https://github.com/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/pull/6,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/pulls/6
lucasb-eyer,pydensecrf,https://api.github.com/repos/lucasb-eyer/pydensecrf/issues/5,125847828,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NTU1NzUxNzc=,5,Fix height width order in dense_inference.py example,802153,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,4,2016-01-10T21:44:59Z,2016-02-06T09:24:33Z,2016-02-06T09:24:33Z,NONE,NA,The proper syntax is `dcrf.DenseCRF2D(img.shape[1], img.shape[0], M)`.
This has to do with C-ordering versus Fortran ordering, also known as https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Row-major_order .
This bug can be highlighted with the following parameters:
Note the straight lines characteristic of a stride misalignement.
On the other hand, `(img.shape[1], img.shape[0])` gives:
This is confirmed by this other Python wrapper for densecrf:
See the order `(D, W, H)` at this line:
while the original 2D code is `(H, W)`.

mangini,gdocs2md,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/65,439096597,MDU6SXNzdWU0MzkwOTY1OTc=,65,Put converted text in a dialogue box instead of emailing (enhancement),1100216,open,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2019-05-01T08:07:00Z,2019-05-01T08:27:30Z,NA,NONE,NA,"I appreciate this script's ability to convert a Docs document to Markdown. It came in very handy.

However, I didn't want the script to email the converted document. The contents of my document were somewhat confidential. I was happier keeping it off the insecure public email system and away from possible eavesdroppers. I preferred to have the script pop up a dialogue box with the converted Markdown text, allowing me to copy the text and paste it into a text editor for further manipulation.

I commented out [Lines 71-77](https://github.com/mangini/gdocs2md/blob/master/converttomarkdown.gapps#L71-L77), which generate an email message with the converted text attached, and put in the following calls:

This worked fine for my one document one time. It would nice to have this integrated into this script somehow. It would probably be better to offer the option of emailing or putting up a dialogue box, instead of hard-coding one or the other. I don't want to take the time right now to design that, so I am not offering a Pull Request. Maybe this request will encourage someone else to do that work. mangini,gdocs2md,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/63,394461662,MDU6SXNzdWUzOTQ0NjE2NjI=,63,Not really an issue - my changes to support a new mode of operation,15029648,open,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2018-12-27T18:35:19Z,2018-12-27T18:35:19Z,NA,NONE,NA,"Hi There,
First off: thanks for providing this code - it has been very helpful for me.

I have made some reasonably big changes - not fixes - but a new mode of operation. I have no idea if you'll be interested in them, but I I just wanted to let you know. Because I have changed the way the script works (not email based any more) it didn't feel like a pull request was suitable.

My requirement was to have the markdown version created in Google Drive alongside the original document (in a ""markdown"" folder) - instead of being emailed. I also needed to enable hyperlinking from one document to another in the same directory or a sub directory. The code now looks at all links - if these refer to a document in the same directory or a sub directory then the absolute link is replaced by just a relative path name. It will also automatically (recursively) process the file being referenced - thus if you process a top level file and this links to a number of sub-files then all of the files will be processed and markdown versions created - all with suitable internal links. All in all this enables large multi-file documentation packages to be maintained in Google Drive then easily exported to Markdown files.
If this is of interest let me know - I've only just finished it and haven't used it much so there will probably be some tweaks/fixes over the next couple of weeks.

>The sharing settings update simplifies sharing settings for documents with attached Apps Script projects by treating them like a single document.
>As a result of the sharing settings update, and according to the document access level, some users may:
>* Gain or lose access to affected projects
>* Change their access levels (for example, owner, editor, reader)
>**This change will not affect sharing settings for the documents. Only sharing settings of attached Apps Script projects will be updated.**

mangini,gdocs2md,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/26,37550930,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTgyMTIxMjk=,26,Support exporting to new files in Drive, and improved handling of bold and italic formatting.",172154,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2014-07-10T10:42:44Z,2015-04-25T08:36:19Z,2015-04-25T08:36:19Z,NONE,NA,"Hi,
Thanks for the converter - just what we needed to get a more useful document format out of Google Drive!

We had some minor problems with the export, where some of our documents had odd italic and bold formatting, which covered leading/trailing whitespace (sometimes even JUST whitespace, e.g. a single ""italic"" space between words). Since this is invisible in the original documents it's hard to correct.

Commit c72c363 deals with this by shrinking the regions of bold and italic formatting to remove leading/trailing whitespace, which removes useless formatting and also makes the output more compliant with markdown.

I've also included commits to make the converter more flexible, by allowing exporting to new files in your drive, and to use a new mimeType so that e.g. stackedit.io will see the files. This also means that when they are downloaded, they have just an ""md"" extension, not "".md.txt"". Finally, it makes nested italic and bold a little neater by breaking up the asterisks so it's easier to read.

Let me know if you would prefer a pull request for just the italic/bold. I've also got a Drive document with some examples of odd formatting that is fixed by the changes. I don't think the changes should break anything, but I could have missed a possibility.

,NA,TRUE,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/26/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/26/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/26/events,https://github.com/mangini/gdocs2md/pull/26,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/pulls/26
mangini,gdocs2md,https://api.github.com/repos/mangini/gdocs2md/issues/25,36019597,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTczMTQyNzM=,25,Improvments and refactoring,305957,open,FALSE,NA,NA,3,2014-06-18T19:33:57Z,2020-10-04T02:54:03Z,NA,NONE,NA,This changes will provides a toolbar integration that allows to either export as email or export as files into GDrive. The recursive code architecture allows to parse the whole document tree, even if table cells are formatted. Researchers greatly benefit from a equation export as LaTex.
- Equation support generates latex equations and puts them into the output markdown surrounded by a $ sign.
- Toolbar integration allows an easier execution of the script.

- Recursive code architecture makes the code cleaner and readable. A document is a tree like structure. This modifications will walk over the whole document tree recursively. Now the script can handle text formats within table cells or bullet point lists.
- Markdown documents can be exported directly as files into Google Drive. A warning is presented if files are about to get overwritten.
- Code fencing is implemented the way GitHub flavored markdown does it.
- Creates GitHub flavored markdown tables instead of HTML tables.

are ALREADY indented by four spaces are getting turned into ""pre"" code.

gets turned into paragraphs for the exdented lines and ""pre"" blocks for the indented
lines, alternating through the block, up to the ---.
I have not tried what happens to normal paragraphs, outside the --- source code
block, that are indented by 4 spaces.
It worked earlier today and I have been getting the script from github each time
I use it so it is likely caused by recent work.

maruel,panicparse,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/57,790805968,MDU6SXNzdWU3OTA4MDU5Njg=,57,Backwards compatibility with tools that are unaware of go modules,15000,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2021-01-21T08:10:58Z,2021-01-21T14:47:58Z,2021-01-21T14:40:00Z,NONE,NA,"Hi there,
thanks for this project, it seems to work very well : ).

Quick Question: Would you be interested in making the library backwards compatible so that it could be imported by go projects that haven't upgraded to go modules yet? This would mainly involve creating a v2 directory inside of the repository and moving the v2 code into a v2 directory as recommended here: https://blog.golang.org/v2-go-modules#TOC_3.
What I mean is that the code below works fine as long as you have `go.mod` file in your project.
However, if you don't have a `go.mod` file, you get an error like this:
main.go:6:2: cannot find package ""github.com/maruel/panicparse/v2/stack"" in any of:
If you're interested, I might be able to send you patch for this, but I figured I reach out first to see how you feel about it.
No worries if you decide you don't want this compatibility, your work on this is much appreciated either way : ).

Interesting package. I think it's suitable for fuzzing. Proposing to get it running on [Fuzzit](https://fuzzit.dev/). They give free service for open source.

They use [go-fuzz](https://github.com/dvyukov/go-fuzz). It's one of these genetic fuzzers, it instruments the binary and tries to traverse all the branches. A local run has built up a corpus of a couple hundred cases. No crashes so far. It seems to be in good shape.
Build will fail due to missing the API key. If you're interested setup is like this:

* In Fuzzit settings grab an API key. In repo settings in [Travis](https://travis-ci.org/) paste it to envvar `FUZZIT_API_KEY`.",NA,TRUE,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/48/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/48/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/48/events,https://github.com/maruel/panicparse/pull/48,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/pulls/48

column1: maruel,panicparse,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/35,274568326,MDU6SXNzdWUyNzQ1NjgzMjY=,35,Create a single GOROOT / GOPATH guesser with a flag to turn that off.,75011,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2017-11-16T15:59:37Z,2018-02-02T14:28:56Z,2018-02-02T14:28:56Z,OWNER,NA,"## Use case
- Build Go executable on CI at path /x
- Runs Go executable on prod at path /y

There's currently an hard coded variable of 'well known goroots' in [stack/stack.go#L63](https://github.com/maruel/panicparse/blob/master/stack/stack.go#L63) to help disambiguation for GOROOT. It's a cheap effort at best. There's no such guessing for GOPATH.

Be more 'smarty pants' about guessing both GOROOT and GOPATH. The way to achieve this is to spot check files in the stack trace, and try to match the two roots by finding the exact match of files. If an exact match is found, use this to rebase the paths.
That said, this kind of 'smart' behaviour can occasionally be counter productive, so a single boolean flag has be provided to disable this completely, i.e. `-norebase`

A naive implementation would be to add two flags to handle absolute path rebasing of `GOROOT` and `GOPATH`, e.g. `-goroot <path>` and `-gopath <path>`. Doing so will be error prone for users, and most users wouldn't realize they need to calculate the values, leading to no source parsing, which is currently the case for the use case above. That's silent failure and nobody likes this.",NA,FALSE,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/35/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/35/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/35/events,https://github.com/maruel/panicparse/issues/35,NA

maruel,panicparse,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/12,119103887,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTkxMDM4ODc=,12,Add bool option to keep full path,75011,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2015-11-26T21:34:59Z,2015-11-30T00:28:51Z,2015-11-30T00:28:51Z,OWNER,NA,The idea is that `pp -full-path` (flag name to be determined) would print the full path of each file instead of the default (base name only).
- Alignment: stdlib vs deep GOPATH package would cause poor alignment.
- Column width: pp tries hard to make the line as short as possible, this wouldn't be possible with full path.
- Some Go users use terminal with white background. I suspect this is mostly caused by OSX's Terminal defaults. I expect little to no Linux and Windows users to use white background.
- Terminal with white background makes yellow and light gray hard to read: http://i.imgur.com/WqNVjfh.png
- Some people cannot distinguish green-red. This is a bigger non-self inflected problem.
1. Make the color palette configurable via an environment variable.
2. Force the background to be black. This would look like hell but would be readable yet very annoying.
3. Try to read the background color and switch color table dynamically (no idea how to achieve this).
4. Change the current colors to use a palette that is both readable with black and white backgrounds.

I think option 1 is preferable but it still has the drawback of not working out of the box, requiring reading the help page, then taking action to make the change permanent. This is clumsy and annoying.
So in the meantime, option 4 is more sensible. I need to play with both 256 and 16 colors terminals to ensure I do not make things worse.

To use pp as a library, I'd like to call it internally from within a recover block. The closest I found was `func ParseDump(r io.Reader, out io.Writer) ([]Goroutine, error)`, which I guess I could pass nil parameters to? Is there a more elegant option?
Thanks, and sorry if I missed something obvious.

maruel,panicparse,https://api.github.com/repos/maruel/panicparse/issues/9,116431029,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTY0MzEwMjk=,9,More aggressive deduplication,318501,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,8,2015-11-11T22:03:52Z,2016-01-04T21:29:20Z,2016-01-04T20:20:12Z,NONE,NA,Hi, thanks for the great tool!

I took a large (20k lines) goroutine dump from a server and I used panicparse to analyze it. Unfortunately panicparse still emits many thousands of lines because lots of goroutines that are the same for my purposes cannot be deduplicated.
I dug into it more and I found two specific issues:
1. Panicparse compares argument values and if it doesn't think they're pointers, it wants the values to be the same. For my purposes, I really don't care about function args
column2: I want two goroutines to be deduped if they have the same stack trace.

column1: In case it helps, here are two lines from two different goroutines that caused them to not be deduped (this is deep in `net`'s inner workings, far away from my own code):
My quick hack was to modify my local copy of stack.go to consider two `Args` to be similar if they have the same number of args (without looking at the args):
2. If a goroutine has been blocked for a long time on e..g a channel op or IO, it prints something like

A difference in # of minutes causes two goroutines not to be deduped. My quick hack here was to modify my trace file with a quick `s/\d+ minutes/123 minutes/`. A more robust solution would be for panicparse to merge multiple values by replacing with `* minutes` (as with merged function params) or, if we want to be fancy, something like `(12-49) minutes`.

I wanted to bring these issues to your attention and see what you think a good solution might be. I'm not sure if, for other people in other contexts, having goroutines not be disambiguated for the above two reasons is useful. If so, perhaps there could be a flag for even more aggressive deduplication.

I have been using hmmlearns GMMHMM (https://hmmlearn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#gmmhmm) for learning hmms where state distributions are gaussian mixtures to better approximate my data. I am now trying to build a similar model with pyhsmm except with the HDP and semi-markovian extensions but I am running into some problems applying EM_fit.
Here is the model set-up for some 2D data X:
mixture_dist = pyhsmm.distributions.MixtureDistribution(alpha_0 = alpha_0, components = [pyhsmm.distributions.Gaussian(**obs_hypparams) for itr in range(nMix)])
# Build the iHSMM model that will represent the fitmodel
model.add_data(X)#,trunc=60) # duration truncation speeds things up when it's possible
Now as far as I can tell my model set-up for this distribution is correct and the Gibbs sampling seems to work, although when running model.EM_fit() I get the error:
<ipython-input-2-4ea26e5a1b5e> in computeAllScores(X, cutPoint, nMix, n_components, randState, nGibbsSamples, useEM, showPlots)
204         step_iterator = range(maxiter) if not progprint else progprint_xrange(maxiter)

So it looks like EM for mixture models has not been incorporated into pyhsmm yet? If so is this something that will be added soon or is work in progress? If this is not going to be added could you please point me in the right direction as to what exactly needs adding to get this to work (as much detail as possible please, first time using these models!)? I guess max_likelihood() must be altered to properly compute likelihoods for mixture models??

mattjj,pyhsmm,https://api.github.com/repos/mattjj/pyhsmm/issues/98,452391948,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0Mjg1Mjg2NjQx,98,Include resampling over (kappa+alpha) and rho=kappa/(kappa+alpha) in WeakLimitStickyHDPHMM,3874391,open,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2019-06-05T09:07:41Z,2019-06-05T09:34:41Z,NA,NONE,NA,"This change follows Algorithm 9 and Appendix C of E. Fox dissertation 2009.

The change reparameterized `alpha` and `kappa` as `(alpha+kappa)` and `rho=kappa/(kappa+alpha)`. We place a Gamma prior over `(alpha+kappa)` and a Beta prior over `rho`. The `WeakLimitStickyHDPHMM` class is updated to allow the new hyper-parameters. Further, the new classes are added to the transitions.py class to include ""FullConcGibbs"" classes to indicate that we are now sampling over all of the hyper-parameters in the model (rather than just the alpha and gamma parameters as before).
I ran the updated model on `example-data.txt` following the code in `hsmm.py` (changing the relevant model to:
The result is that we now have a posterior over kappa:
I'd very much appreciate it if you have any comments/suggestions/reviews.

fails, unless I first install future manually.

Second, I was looking at the paper ""The Infinite Hidden Markov Model"" by Beal et. al.  The first example that they give is of the string 30*'ABCDEFEDCB', and remark that the most parsimonious HMM which models this has 10 states.  I'm assuming that the WeakLimitHDPHMM will essentially run their algorithm (of course I have to give a maximum number of states).   I defined the following function:
def trainHDPHMM(data, Nmax, iterations=100, alpha_0=1.0, alpha_size=None):
It sometimes (it depends on the random seed) gets a traceback like (even though I've done

But now to what I'm really interested in:

In the paper ""Particle Gibbs for Infinite Hidden Markov Models"" by Tripuraneni et. al. (in NIPS 2015) they describe a method using particle Gibbs to resample the state trajectory which, they say, greatly sped up apparent convergence. I ran pyhsmm on discrete (binary) outputs and fed it strongly periodic data, i.e.: `0,1,0,1,0,1....` and asked it to predict next 10 outputs.

In a 2-hidden state (parametric) Bayesian HMM, there would be two hypotheses: (1) the data were produced by a single hidden state that emits 1 with probability 0.5, or (2) the data were produced by a periodic transitioning between two hidden states, one which emits 1 with probability ~1.0, and another that emits 0 with probability ~1.0. If you had a sparse prior on the emission matrix, but less sparse prior on the transition matrix, you'd favor hypothesis 2 and your posterior would predict periodic observations.

pyhsmm doesn't predict the periodic trend even with a larger set of observations, as far as I can tell. It also uses the max number of states (~25) which seems too large for this data. Is because of my hyperparameter settings? Is it possible to get better inferences by forcing sparsity on the observation matrix and using more concentrated priors for the global HDP?
I attach plots of predicted posteriors from two independent runs (same settings). My code is below. Thanks!
# strongly periodic data, except for first four observations

I am using pyhsmm for a research project (thanks for making this public, it's awesome!) and I wanted to use a slightly different observation distribution, or rather different prior on the observation distribution, namely a scaled inverse whishart or separated correlation/variance matrices (see http://www.themattsimpson.com/2012/08/20/prior-distributions-for-covariance-matrices-the-scaled-inverse-wishart-prior/) as a prior for the covariance matrices.

My questions is whether this can be done just by extending the Gaussian class in pybasicbayes (https://github.com/mattjj/pybasicbayes/blob/master/pybasicbayes/distributions/gaussian.py), or do I have to change things inside of the Gibbs sampler as well?
If extending the Gaussian class is enough, which functions need to be implemented/changed. Would mirroring IsotropicGaussian be enough despite the '# TODO collapsed, meanfield, max_likelihood' ?
Happy to make a pull request back into the project if I get it to work :)

mattjj,pyhsmm,https://api.github.com/repos/mattjj/pyhsmm/issues/39,59327387,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MzAyMTkzNTQ=,39,setup.py that works with pip and doesn't rely on Cython for source distributions,96318,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,9,2015-02-28T05:53:53Z,2015-11-03T03:12:47Z,2015-11-03T03:12:47Z,COLLABORATOR,NA,A revised setup.py that: (i) works with `pip install`, (ii) correctly distributes Cython-generated files when making a source distribution, and (iii) doesn't rely on Cython being installed when installing a source distribution (just compiles the Cython-generated cpp code).
A couple of other changes in this pull request:

2. Added a `clean` option to `setup.py` that removes Cython-generated code (*.cpp, *.c, *.so) and build-related files. Intended to be used only by developers - very useful for testing code. Note that this relies on all the .cpp/.c files in `pyhsmm/` being Cython-generated.
3. Removed Cython from being an installation dependency of pyhsmm. It's not necessary for automatic installations like from pypi
4. Added notes for developers in `developer_notes.md` - if these are useful they can be incorporated into the README.md or to a separate developer's pyhsmm guide if you make one.
Here's how I tested the source distribution creation/installation:
# send dist/pyhsmm-0.x.x.tar.gz to a fresh box
# try to install it on fresh box
# this will install by compiling Cython-generated source code, without needing Cython or using *.pyx files at all
To test the installation from the github repo, I just did:
This will apply Cython to the *.pyx files to generate the cpp code, and then install the package.
If both of these work, then we're good for both the automatic installation with pip and the developer's build case.

If that sounds good you, I can make a similar fix for `pybasicbayes` (to make it handle Cython correctly), and then add travis CI support for `pyhsmm` to make the testing more streamlined. The only missing ingredient then would be a unit testing main driver script.

mattjj,pyhsmm,https://api.github.com/repos/mattjj/pyhsmm/issues/35,59188331,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MzAxNDEyNTc=,35,Fixup for pypi distribution of pyhsmm,96318,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,17,2015-02-27T04:34:51Z,2015-02-27T13:31:51Z,2015-02-27T04:57:06Z,COLLABORATOR,NA,I missed one wrinkle with pypi distribution. The previous version didn't include the *.pyx files in the distribution, and so the package from pypi would install correctly but would not compile the Cython files.

For now, I included the Cython files and associated headers through `MANIFEST.in`. This will make it so when you install the package from pypi, the installation procedure automatically compiles the Cython files. A more ideal solution would be to write a conditional in the `setup.py` that checks if Cython is present, and if so, compiles the Cython files. For developers who want to make a distribution with `python setup.py sdist`, only the Cython-generated *.c files would go in the distribution, and then users could install with just Python and a C compiler, without needing Cython. (This more ideal setup is described here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4505747/how-should-i-structure-a-python-package-that-contains-cython-code). Since your users are mostly expert developers who probably have Cython, I figured it's not pressing.

One caveat to watch out for: if you compile your pyx files to make *.c files, and have something that includes all *.c files in `MANIFEST.in`, you could accidentally package a Cython generated, e.g.  foo.c along with a foo.pyx file. That could might create a situation where only the foo.c gets used even if it's out of date with the foo.pyx file. So to be on safe side, best to wipe out all Cython generated files before making a source distribution, i.e. before running `python setup.py sdist`.
I fixed this in `pybasicbayes` too, see other pull request.

It'd be great if you could make a fresh source distribution and upload it to pypi. You could wipe out the previous one through the pypi admin settings, or upgrade the VERSION variable in setup.py and make a new version release. I'm sure that if you wipe out the previous one and replace it without changing the version, you won't upset anyone, it has only been out for a few hours :)

mattjj,pyhsmm,https://api.github.com/repos/mattjj/pyhsmm/issues/16,17209711,MDU6SXNzdWUxNzIwOTcxMQ==,16,better parallel interface,1458824,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2013-07-25T12:56:46Z,2013-07-29T14:27:20Z,2013-07-29T14:27:20Z,OWNER,NA,One should only need to do this after starting engines:
import pyhsmm.parallel # creates client and stuff
# or this, which could be greedy or smart

Each sequence should be sent to only one engine (load balancing based on greedy sequence length balancing and assuming all engines are about the same speed), and each engine will only resample on its assigned data. If data added to the model with add_data already exists on some engine (checked via hash), don't broadcast it
column2: if it doesn't exist on the engines, send it to one.

column1: There should be another dynamic load balancing mode which does the current thing: load all data on each engine and dispatch resampling tasks dynamically. Maybe something like this:

mattjj,pyhsmm,https://api.github.com/repos/mattjj/pyhsmm/issues/10,13470470,MDU6SXNzdWUxMzQ3MDQ3MA==,10,Use of prior information for segmentation,376997,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2013-04-22T09:00:06Z,2013-04-22T10:43:54Z,2013-04-22T10:43:54Z,NONE,NA,Hi Matt, Hope everything is going well with you.

I was wondering what would be a effective way of including prior information for a change-point/segmentation using the Sticky-HMM. In particular I have a set of sequences of which there is a previously generated high quality segmentation. I would like to use that information in order to speed up and help segmenting new data.
What I did think it may be possible it was:
- to start a model with these pre-segmented data
- update the distribution parameters without up-dating the state sequences
- load the new data and update all parameters of the model but only the state sequences of the new data, i.e., keeping the state sequences of the all data constant.

Does this sounds like something good? or perhaps it would be better to remove the pre-segmented data prior to loading and analyzing the new data. I imagine if I keep the pre-segmented data in the model will be pull towards that answer (to some extent) but if I remove it then i would be only having  smart start for the distribution and transition parameters.

I have created a resample_model_parallel2 function which resamples the observation distributions in parrallel. This was at the cost of pushing the model into the engines an additional time. However, on my test this had very minor overload. I have added code to parallel.py .. that was easy!!! given the code you had in there already.
In my initial test with Nmax = 100 the execution time came down to half :)

i did not see a way to parallelise the sampling of the trans_dist but let me know if you think it is possible  I can work on it. resampling of the initial state is super quick anyways so no  point in speeding that up.

mathiasbynens,he,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/he/issues/77,546950374,MDU6SXNzdWU1NDY5NTAzNzQ=,77,"Section 12.2.4.69 of the HTML spec, referenced in README.md, does not exist",18180119,open,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2020-01-08T15:57:47Z,2020-04-08T20:22:35Z,NA,NONE,NA,"There is an issue with the reference to the HTML spec in README.md in the following part:

> This function takes a string of HTML and decodes any named and numerical character references in it using the [algorithm described in section 12.2.4.69 of the HTML spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/syntax.html#tokenizing-character-references).

There is a section 12.2.5.69 but that does not contain any relevant algorithm.
The reference to the HTML spec should either be fixed and changed to the correct section with the link fixed to go to that section, or it should be removed entirely.

mathiasbynens,he,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/he/issues/50,181780638,MDU6SXNzdWUxODE3ODA2Mzg=,50,Edge case: does not decode example string on w3 spec,19825876,open,FALSE,81942,NA,4,2016-10-07T22:28:43Z,2019-10-02T03:38:20Z,NA,NONE,NA,I was testing encode/decode via https://mothereff.in/html-entities while cross-referencing the spec, and I noticed that `he` is not able to decode certain named references correctly. On the [w3 spec page](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/syntax.html#tokenizing-character-references), it lists this example string, `I'm &notit
column2: I tell you`, which should be parsed into `I'm ¬it
column3: I tell you` with a parse error. `he` returns the string un-parsed. It appears that `he` is not able to parse legacy named references if there are one or more alphanumeric characters after the legacy named reference **followed** by a semicolon `
column4: ` character. `he` parses correctly if the tail of alphanumeric characters ends with a character other than semicolon.

column1: Currently it instead returns actual ""unsafe"" `\u0000` string.
Thanks for all your hard work on the library and the awesome documentation!
I did a performance test recently between he.decode() and using [this trick](http://stackoverflow.com/a/7394787) to use the browser's `<textarea>` element to do the conversion for me.

Surprisingly, I found that `he.decode()` was 2x slower for my string than using the browser's textarea. Here is the code I used to run my benchmarks. The `<script>` src at the top should be changed to point to your `he.js` script location:
console.info(""Time Taken (using new txtarea each time):"", (b - a)/1000, 'seconds.')
console.info(""Time Taken (using HtmlEntities library function):"", (b - a)/1000, 'seconds.')
Just wanted to point out this interesting comparison. It isn't really an issue so you can close this!

`\u2026` is being decoded correctly both from `hellip` and `mldr` named entities.
However, when encoding, `\u2026` is encoded into `mldr`.
I traversed quite few Unicode reference pages and everywhere the default named entity is referenced as `hellip`.
Please consider switching the encoding to `hellip` named entity because it is easier to remember and matches majority of reference sources on the Internet.

From your experience on he, do you think that is feasible / that would make sense ?

It's just for UX, I'd still be using `he` in the server.

I'd love to use this library in [my polyfill for the iframe `srcdoc` attribute](https://github.com/jugglinmike/srcdoc-polyfill), but I think I need an additional feature. The functionality I'm proposing here would help me to resolve [an issue that was recently filed against that project](https://github.com/jugglinmike/srcdoc-polyfill/issues/5).
> Although `he.escape` allows for escaping ""unsafe"" markup characters,
> there is currently no way to escape the inverse set--non-ASCII
> characters only. This is useful in contexts where markup is allowed, but
> non-ASCII characters might be otherwise mangled (as in the iframe
> Introduce a new option to `he.encode` which disables the escaping of
> unsafe markup characters. Preserve API compatability by disabling this

column2: ` is an invalid character reference (parse error) but then again, using the raw U+0080 character [is just as invalid](http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/parsing.html#preprocessing-the-input-stream). The difference is that U+0080 in HTML source gets ignored, while `&#x80
column3: ` becomes `€` due to the overrides table.

column1: Should we continue to return invalid entities, knowing they might map to a completely different symbol? Or should we not escape any invalid code points in the input? Or should we strip invalid characters from the input?
Should there be a `strict` option for `encode` as well (just like there is for `decode`) which errors in case an invalid character is part of the source?

mathiasbynens,he,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/he/issues/18,33258978,MDU6SXNzdWUzMzI1ODk3OA==,18,For strictly browser-side code, is there any reason to use this library in favour of hacks involving DOM elements' innerHTML and innerText properties?",2358339,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,6,2014-05-11T10:20:28Z,2019-12-16T11:57:05Z,2014-05-11T19:33:37Z,NONE,NA,"Consider the following Stack Overflow [answer](http://stackoverflow.com/a/1395954/1709587) to the question [How to decode HTML entities using jQuery?](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1147359/how-to-decode-html-entities-using-jquery)
> where `encoded` is your string containing HTML entities that you wish to decode.
> This works similarly to the accepted answer, but is safe to use with untrusted user input.
> As noted by Mike Samuel, doing this with a `<div>` instead of a `<textarea>` with untrusted user input is an XSS vulnerability, even if the `<div>` is never added to the DOM:
> // Shows the alert in Firefox and Safari (and returns an empty string)

> However, this attack is not possible against a `<textarea>` because there are no HTML elements that are permitted content of a `<textarea>`. Consequently, any HTML tags still present in the 'encoded' string will be automatically entity-encoded by the browser.
> // This is safe (and returns the right answer)

Previously, the answer just included the first code snippet. I recently edited the answer to note the rationale behind using a `textarea` instead of a `div`. However, I'm a little uneasy, because I know that your library exists and is not (as far as I can tell) strictly targeting node users. I find myself wondering why.

I'll probably post a link to this library as an answer (unless you'd like to do so yourself) to that question regardless, since I figure that people who are using node may benefit from having a single solution that is usable both clientside and serverside. But how about everyone else? What reason is there for anyone to serve a 300 line script to serve a purpose that can - it seems to my naive eyes - be done in 50 characters with a clever hack?

Are there any situations at all in which the `textarea` hack fails (or at least is not guaranteed by spec to succeed)? I confess to being slightly uneasy about it since I don't know where (or for that matter, if) the spec determines the behaviour of browsers when presented with HTML elements containing disallowed children, like
I'm not really supposed to be here.
but from the testing I've done, it seems to work.

Sorry to offload a question like this onto you, but it seems to be right in your area of expertise and is relevant when figuring out to whom this library is useful. (Indeed, if there _is_ something profoundly wrong with the `textarea` hack, it almost seems worth noting that in this library's README - otherwise, the case for using a library for this purpose at all is unclear).

mathiasbynens,he,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/he/issues/5,16082071,MDU6SXNzdWUxNjA4MjA3MQ==,5,decode(): Support the different parsing mode that is used in attribute values,81942,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2013-06-27T11:47:51Z,2013-06-28T08:40:05Z,2013-06-27T15:14:36Z,OWNER,NA,http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/tokenization.html#character-reference-in-attribute-value-state
> If the character reference is being consumed as part of an attribute, and the last character matched is not a U+003B SEMICOLON character (`
column2: `), and the next character is either a U+003D EQUALS SIGN character (`=`) or an alphanumeric ASCII character, then, for historical reasons, all the characters that were matched after the U+0026 AMPERSAND character (`&`) must be unconsumed, and nothing is returned. However, if this next character is in fact a U+003D EQUALS SIGN character (`=`), then this is a parse error, because some legacy user agents will misinterpret the markup in those cases.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/938,778452568,MDU6SXNzdWU3Nzg0NTI1Njg=,938,[Better Way] No Symlinks with usage as a bare repository - README needs updation.,73003119,open,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2021-01-04T23:42:05Z,2021-01-04T23:42:05Z,NA,NONE,NA,"Manging dotfiles using symlink has been like a tradition and almost all the developers are doing it, if not having multiple copies of there dotfiles . **But there exists a much better way** - people at atlassian has written a very nice article about it using the git's `--bare` feature and using it to store the dotfiles and I have to say this, it very elegant. The trick to managing these dotfiles is by creating a [bare](https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/setting-up-a-repository/git-init) git repository.

**The reason for this Issue is to make people aware about way and this repository is the best place for it, cause lets face it every developer trying to customize there os has or will peek into this repo atleast once.**
## Managing and tracking [dot]files with bare repo
Clone the repo as a bare repository and thats it! no problems related to symlinks.
# after forking replace the <username> with your github handle

> Notice the `--bare` flag, this the clones repository as a bare repository. Bare repository are special in a way that they omit working directory, therefore to use a bare repository, first we need to define the following.
> - `--work-tree` - this can be your home directory, i.e., `$HOME` or `~`)
> Therefore the command to use the repository will have a prefix `git --git-dir=$HOME/.dotfiles --work-tree=$HOME `,
Now next step is to checkout to the proper branch according to the os of the machine.
# checkout to main for macos and linux for ubuntu.
This method of managing and sharing has various advantages some of them are shown below:
**1. Keep the dofitles versioned, (basically all the cons of using git)**

At this point, all your configuration files are being tracked, and you can easily use the `dotfiles` command ([see this line in .aliases](https://github.com/kalkayan/dotfiles/blob/main/.aliases#L69)) to manage the repository, some examples are:-
# to check the status of the tracked and untracked files
# to add a file for tracking
# push new files or changes to the github
> :warning: The `dotfiles status` will show all the untracked files to disable this behavior, do the following
> # to remove the untracked directories and files from the listing
Share the same configs of multiple devices with minimal changes using `branch`, create a branch for your new machine, example:-
# Create configurations specific to your aws machines
Create configs based on your environment using `branch`, create a branch and configure according to you work env.
# Manage multiple profiles - check out to the work profile

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/842,352129670,MDU6SXNzdWUzNTIxMjk2NzA=,842,Can't disable local time machine snapshots in (High) Sierra,6443573,open,FALSE,NA,NA,6,2018-08-20T13:14:18Z,2019-03-18T15:40:40Z,NA,NONE,NA,"The option in `.macos` to disable local snapshots (time machine) is redundant, because `tmutil` does not have the option `disablelocal` anymore. As far as I know this applies to Sierra and High Sierra.

There is no substitute for this functionality, so the option should be deleted. All you can do is check if  any local snapshot is stored (`tmutil listlocalsnapshots /`) and delete then one by one if necessary (`tmutil deletelocalsnapshots [date]`).",NA,FALSE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/842/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/842/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/842/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/842,NA

They can now be found here: `~/Library/Application\ Support/Spectacle/Shortcuts.json`

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/783,227538839,MDU6SXNzdWUyMjc1Mzg4Mzk=,783,Recommend Menloco as a good replacement for Monaco font,2346707,open,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2017-05-10T00:55:38Z,2017-06-21T22:21:57Z,NA,NONE,NA,"I couldn't help [noticing this](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/blob/270f3d3/.bash_prompt#L6) in `.bash_prompt`:
# iTerm → Profiles → Text → use 13pt Monaco with 1.1 vertical spacing.

A while ago I [patched the Monaco](https://github.com/Alhadis/Menloco) font to use [Menlo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menlo_%28typeface%29)'s box-drawing glyphs, which ***vastly*** improves the appearance of grids and tables in the terminal:

Since it's a commercially-licensed typeface, I couldn't upload the modified version without infringing on copyright. So I wrote a FontForge script that actually automates the modifications I made to Monaco... just to have prettier-looking borders. =)

I don't know how or where you'd go about mentioning it (or if it's even worth mentioning at all), but I feel like bringing it up - since it's something I know many macOS users would enjoy, haha.",NA,FALSE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/783/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/783/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/783/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/783,NA

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/748,199440394,MDU6SXNzdWUxOTk0NDAzOTQ=,748,use m-cli instead of manually defaults-writing,17790097,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2017-01-08T19:26:22Z,2017-01-08T19:35:31Z,2017-01-08T19:30:21Z,NONE,NA,"@mathiasbynens I have come back to your `.macos` dotfiles regularly for years to see whether new versions of macOS have changed/broken some of my beloved `defaults write` commands before I actually install the OS.  Unfortunately I need to go to about 9 different repos to get a good handle on it, and even then it doesn't cover everything.
The reason is that, for these commands, there is no ""one place"" to compile all of the information about them.  So knowledge is strewn all over the internet.

I've spent the last three days converting all of my scripts and `defaults write` commands over to `m-cli`.  I feel as though, due to its popularity and the fact that it's ""just bash"", `m-cli` is a perfect place for us to begin to consolidate this information.

Please take a look at [my PR](https://github.com/rgcr/m-cli/pull/102) and I think you'll see that this is a vastly superior solution to what we've been doing for the last 5 years.",NA,FALSE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/748/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/748/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/748/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/748,NA

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/698,170502951,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0ODA4NTU5Mzg=,698,enable access to GNU coreutils man pages,10197506,open,FALSE,NA,NA,11,2016-08-10T19:49:48Z,2020-06-16T07:06:59Z,NA,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,`brew.sh` will install `coreutils`, but doesn't configure `.bash_profile` to enable access to their `man` pages. ,NA,TRUE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/698/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/698/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/698/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/pull/698,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/pulls/698
mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/697,170502072,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0ODA4NTUyOTA=,697,use LSCOLORS with BSD ls or LS_COLORS with GNU ls,10197506,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2016-08-10T19:45:33Z,2016-08-11T16:00:00Z,2016-08-11T16:00:00Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,`brew.sh` will install `coreutils` and `bash 4` to use instead of BSD's utilities and `bash 3.6` (or whatever comes with OS X). `.aliases` checks for your `ls` flavor (BSD or GNU), but doesn't take into consideration that the implementations differ in their coloring environment variable - `$LSCOLORS` for BSD, `$LS_COLORS` for GNU.

Also, they follow different color specification formats, so I also configured color-definition strings for both versions. For GNU, it's just like the Mathias's version but with directories colored red, and for BSD it's similar.

,NA,TRUE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/697/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/697/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/697/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/pull/697,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/pulls/697
mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/696,170393452,MDU6SXNzdWUxNzAzOTM0NTI=,696,Downward scrolling with trackpad in man pages not working,10197506,open,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2016-08-10T11:21:42Z,2016-10-31T21:25:26Z,NA,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,When I open a man page in the terminal, I can't scroll down with the trackpad, but only with the up\down keys. If I scroll down with the _down key_, only then I'm able to use the trackpad to scroll _up_, and also to scroll _down_ as much as has been scrolled down with the down key.
the environment variable `LS_COLORS` defined in `.aliases` doesn't work in `Terminal.app`.
The definition used is compatible with Linux, not with OS X. Also, in OS X the variable's name should be `LSCOLORS` (without the underscore).
Please refer to my version of my file (line 33, latest commit af9ab14) to see a working definition for this variable.

,NA,FALSE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/694/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/694/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/694/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/694,NA
mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/693,169739557,MDU6SXNzdWUxNjk3Mzk1NTc=,693,[.macos] Add Finder sidebar (com.apple.sidebarlists) user defaults,11077599,open,FALSE,NA,NA,3,2016-08-06T09:56:50Z,2017-03-15T16:17:00Z,NA,NONE,NA,I think I found a way to set Finder sidebar user defaults.

I often wondered why doing `defaults read com.apple.finder > default.txt`, add some sidebar items, `defaults read com.apple.finder > custom.txt` then `diff default.txt custom.txt` didn't show anything.

Googling ‘finder sidebar defaults write’ might have given me [some clues](https://discussions.apple.com/thread/6430038?start=0&tstart=0). As it appears, Finder's sidebar user defaults (`com.apple.sidebarlists`) are different than Finder's user defaults (`com.apple.finder`).
Also, I'll write this as some sort of tutorial, in case some people would like to join us in a world of undocumented boring reverse-engineering.
Let's start by deleting Finder & Finder's sidebar user defaults.

Let's then remake Finder's sidebar user defaults, tinker around with Finder's sidebar preferences via GUI then [save those [for later comparison]](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/files/404954/default.txt).
Let's now invert Finder's sidebar preferences via GUI so that what was enabled becomes disabled and what was disabled becomes enabled [just clicking each item once].
The following example is just a sample of the results [for the sake of brevity].
As it can be observed, those are what I was first looking for, though `diff`'s output is just a teeny-tiny part of the hole string.
Looking at `custom.txt`'s first lines tells me that this might be kind of similar to setting Dock's arrays items.

What I wonder now is how to use `defaults write` to set those with a shell script. I'll tinker a bit more with this and try to come up with a solution. The problem is: what do those hex values mean? Taking a wild guess, I'd say it might be the path the sidebar item links to and maybe the position in the list (though it may be determined by the order it appears in the user defaults). There are other properties I don't get the point of. This looks like a crossover between Finder aliases and Dock items.
**PS:** This is just the beginning. When I'll have figured out how to do this, I will try to add non native items to Finder's sidebar (such as second-party personal directories).

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/665,155865587,MDU6SXNzdWUxNTU4NjU1ODc=,665,Simplify Custom Terminal Theme,1791092,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2016-05-20T00:41:03Z,2016-05-20T09:17:17Z,2016-05-20T08:00:29Z,NONE,NA,Hi, I think there is a more concise way to do [this](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/blob/40fd8cc726742f5d152afc5dc99aab1f8ac4c888/.osx#L567-L612)
# open the custom theme so it gets added to the list
# wait for 5 seconds to make sure custom theme was added
defaults write com.apple.Terminal ""Default Window Settings"" -string ""Solarized Dark Alyda""
defaults write com.apple.Terminal ""Startup Window Settings"" -string ""Solarized Dark Alyda""
I tried a 1 second wait and it did not work so I upped it to 5. 3 is probably good but I didn't feel like playing with it.
Figured out some of it on my own and from [this guy](https://www.skrauth.de/blog/2015/osx-settings-via-terminal/).

Change GREP_OPTIONS=--color=auto in .exports to aliases to avoid errors.
The GREP_OPTIONS environment variable is deprecated in GNU grep 2.21.
(But not so in OS X grep 2.5.1-FreeBSD.)
To avoid errors such as this:

column2: please use an alias or script

column1: grep color support was moved from .exports to .aliases as follows:
# Move export GREP_OPTIONS=""--color=auto"" (which is deprecated in GNU grep)

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/522,66705253,MDU6SXNzdWU2NjcwNTI1Mw==,522,.extra resources ideas,718272,open,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2015-04-06T21:03:30Z,2015-04-06T21:03:30Z,NA,NONE,NA,A few ideas that may or may not fit into this project:
1. Adding popular .extra setups to the README?  It may be beneficial for people to see how others are customising this setup in an extensible way.

2. Adding an option to the bootstrap.sh to bootstrap with a given .extra repo url.  While maintaining my own [extras-toolbelt](https://github.com/bwvoss/mathiasbynens-dotfiles-extras-toolbelt), it would be nice to run bootstrap.sh, and it prompt for a link to clone a .extra file before sourcing happens, or something fully automated for users that do like the .extra approach.
I could also see where both of these aren't solving that big of a problem, but I wanted to see what some of you thought.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/517,64657676,MDU6SXNzdWU2NDY1NzY3Ng==,517,SystemAudioVolume not working in Yosemite,716307,open,FALSE,NA,NA,8,2015-03-26T23:45:15Z,2020-04-15T23:00:04Z,NA,NONE,NA,Disabling the startup chime has stopped working with Yosemite, I'm afraid. Or at least I can't make it work.
Running `sudo nvram SystemAudioVolume="" ""` works as expected since the new value is reflected in `sudo nvram -p`. However, upon reboot, the startup chime comes to greet me as usual.

Running `sudo nvram -p` afterwards shows that the value has gone back to the default `L`, so it would seem as if Yosemite resets the value to its default on reboot and before the chime, so the change is never made effective.

I've found [this question in AskDifferent](http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/168092/disable-yosemite-startup-sound), but they haven't concluded anything. Maybe somebody here faced the same problem with better luck?

I decided to add my settings to my `.osx` as well. Here’s the script I hacked together to extract the current Spectacle.app defaults:

for key in MakeLarger MakeSmaller MoveToBottomDisplay MoveToBottomHalf MoveToCenter MoveToFullscreen MoveToLeftDisplay MoveToLeftHalf MoveToLowerLeft MoveToLowerRight MoveToNextDisplay MoveToNextThird MoveToPreviousDisplay MoveToPreviousThird MoveToRightDisplay MoveToRightHalf MoveToTopDisplay MoveToTopHalf MoveToUpperLeft MoveToUpperRight RedoLastMove UndoLastMove

# Get information about an IP (ASN number, owner, etc.). Works with domains, too.
# It simply looks up the IP at spameatingmonkey.net over DNS. Does not work with IPv6, unfortunately.
# Return an IP address in reverse form. Works with IPv6, too. Actually this is a helper function for asn().
The alias `myasn` echoes the ASN info for the current `ip`.
Maybe this is of interest for anyone :)

defaults write NSGlobalDomain NSTextShowsControlCharacters -bool true`   seems to cause my Apple Mail app  (MBP 2014 15"" Retina OSX 10.10.1) to irreparably freeze when scrolling up and down the message list.  This was a really weird issue that I thought had to do with the scroll settings, but when setting `defaults delete NSGlobalDomain NSTextShowsControlCharacters`, the issue was resolved.

Again,  not sure how widespread this issue is, but I thought I would pass it along.   Happy to pass along any of the forensics, but since this isn't really software, but rather configuration, I thought it might help someone one day.

I do work with modifiers, but on inspection of the plist files, they seem to be set correctly. :s

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/458,49012913,MDU6SXNzdWU0OTAxMjkxMw==,458,Set default apps for each filetype,3751801,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2014-11-16T19:42:20Z,2014-11-16T22:11:21Z,2014-11-16T22:11:21Z,NONE,NA,I've been investigating how to set default apps for each filetype throght a shell script. I want to know if people think that this can be helpful or it only adds more complexity and innecessary lines of code to dotfiles. So far I've discovered this:
- Launch service handlers info is stored in `~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.LaunchServices/com.apple.launchservices.secure.plist`
- The entry is called `LSHandlers` and is an array that contents dicts, each dict contais the specific content type and the default app to handle it
- Changes only be applied after restarting the Mac
- You can change your default web browser using `LSHandlers`
After investigate about LSHandlers, I've created three methods to change how apps manage each filetype, here's what I've created so far:
**1. Create a function that iterates through each array item in LSHandler**
- It adds or change only one entry without affect the rest
- You can search and modify only the filetype you want
- Due the previous facts this method is more secure because it doesn't affect previous settings
- More complex than the other one method
- It requires more lines of code
# Example: set Sublime Text 3 as default app to open Markdown files
**2. Use `defaults -add-array` to add items to an array of dicts**
- It uses `defaults` command which is better known that `PListtBuddy`
- It create duplicated items that are handled and removed automatically by the system after restart
- Due the previous fact this method is lazy, I've tested with some apps in Yosemite and it and works well
# This add only one entry without removing previous entries, the after restart
# the system automatically removes previous entry with the same filetype value stored
**2. Use `defaults -array` to create a new array of dicts and remove previous**
- It uses `defaults` command which is better known that `PListtBuddy`
- This let you set only the `LSHandlers` you want to use removing previous
- This **removes all previous `LSHandlers`**  and it can create unexpected behaviours, this can be dangerous
- You should track all the `LSHandlers`of your system each time you run `.osx` file to avoid errors
# This removes all previous entries and add only one for markdown files

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/447,47543128,MDU6SXNzdWU0NzU0MzEyOA==,447,Expected `mkd()` functionality,739656,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2014-11-02T17:49:17Z,2014-11-05T17:20:00Z,2014-11-05T17:20:00Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,As currently authored, `mkd` can accept a list of parameters, which will be created as directories, the first of which will be entered with `cd`.
# Create a new directory and enter it

I'd like to suggest the function be updated to use `$_`,  which [expands to the last argument to the previous command, after expansion](http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Special-Parameters.html).
# Create a new directory and enter it

Simply, this will enter the last directory created, rather than the first. (When only one parameter is passed, the last directory created is also the first). I'm not sure if this would be the expected behavior, and I'm sure this is a relatively rare use case, but it may be worth thinking about, or adding additional comments to further define the functionality.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/420,40912133,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjAxNzM4NjM=,420,Enable vim 'brackedted mode' (see http://stackoverflow.com/a/7053522/31493),233589,open,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2014-08-22T14:14:01Z,2020-06-16T07:07:12Z,NA,NONE,NA,As of Mac OS X Lion 10.7, Terminal supports “bracketed paste mode,” which enables the terminal emulator to tell the program connected to the tty when the user pastes text, so that the program won’t interpret it as editing commands. Programs that support it send the terminal an escape sequence to enable this mode, in which the terminal surrounds pasted text with a pair of escape sequences that identify the start and end.
(code and description by Cris Page, see StackOverflow link)

[filetype](http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/options.html#%3asetfiletype) is set implicitly, without using setfiletype, because `*.md` is already associated with Modula-2 files and `setfiletype` doesn't allow `filetype` to be set twice.
[setlocal](http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/options.html#:setlocal) is used to apply a new `filetype` value for each Markdown file as it is being added to the buffer.

,NA,TRUE,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/419/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/419/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/419/events,https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/pull/419,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/pulls/419
mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/418,40860093,MDU6SXNzdWU0MDg2MDA5Mw==,418,Files with *.md extensions are not recognized as Markdown files,205659,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,4,2014-08-21T23:05:37Z,2014-08-22T19:54:31Z,2014-08-22T19:54:31Z,NONE,NA,Files ending with `*.md` are identified as [Modula-2](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modula-2) files. The biggest problem with this is that `'` symbols break the whole layout of a Markdown document. Here is an example:
Vim correctly recognizes files with extensions `*.markdown` and `*.mdown` as Markdown files.

Now, I know who Niklaus Wirth is and I respect him dearly. That said, Markdown is more than 3 times as popular as Modula-2 according to the [WebSource.it comparison](http://www.websource.it/search/markdown/modula-2) and the gap will probably continue to rise. And quite frankly, when was the last time you wrote that shiny Modula-2 application? What about a Markdown document?

Git 2.0 from 'matching' to 'simple'. To squelch this message
and maintain the traditional behavior, use:
To squelch this message and adopt the new behavior now, use:
When push.default is set to 'matching', git will push local branches
to the remote branches that already exist with the same name.
Since Git 2.0, Git defaults to the more conservative 'simple'
behavior, which only pushes the current branch to the corresponding
remote branch that 'git pull' uses to update the current branch.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/397,35677188,MDU6SXNzdWUzNTY3NzE4OA==,397,Whois alias broken,739656,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,5,2014-06-13T14:41:39Z,2014-07-05T06:01:15Z,2014-07-05T06:01:15Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,The following alias doesn't appear to be working correctly on 10.9.3
According to the `man` page a variant of `whois-servers.net` is used by default, so not only is it apparently broken, it's also unnecessary.
Use the specified host instead of the default variant.  Either a host name or an IP address may be specified.

By default whois constructs the name of a whois server to use from the top-level domain (TLD) of the supplied (single) argument, and appending "".whois-servers.net"".  This effectively allows a suitable whois server to be selected automatically for a large number of TLDs.

In the event that an IP address is specified, the whois server will default to the American Registry for Internet Numbers (ARIN).  If a query to ARIN references APNIC, LACNIC, or RIPE, that server will be queried also, provided that the -Q option is not specified.
If the query is not a domain name or IP address, whois will fall back to whois.crsnic.net.
There are other whois proxies, [`whois.geektools.com`](http://www.geektools.com/faq.html) for example, but I'll leave that up to your discretion.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/366,30926874,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTQ0MjAwMDU=,366,Improve Git configuration,506129,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2014-04-05T23:48:06Z,2014-06-14T13:13:37Z,2014-06-07T14:35:48Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,- More aliases. Even shorthands for faster everyday Git on the command line.
All of the previous aliases are kept except the `p` which is now `pl`.
Added more documentation and configuration references to aliases.
It is quite useful for diffing code with brackets.
- Some other minor configurations like colors.
- Everything is properly commented and sorted alphabetically.
I think I have a slightly better and more extensive Git configuration which could be of help to others.
It is based on your previous `.gitconfig` and other dotfiles repos ([skwp](https://github.com/skwp/dotfiles/blob/master/git/gitconfig)).
Normally I would make multiple pull requests for every change, but this could be a lot of burden for both of us.
I am happy to make any changes and even make it completely backwards compatible with your configuration. Just let me know.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/351,28770082,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTMxOTkxNTY=,351,Don't treat indents with > 8 spaces as an error,830004,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2014-03-05T07:22:52Z,2014-07-10T14:49:38Z,2014-03-05T07:37:57Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,Don't use `indent-with-non-tab`. This config flag is PERNICIOUS. If turned on, git won't tell you that you indented your code incorrectly. Instead, when it is pushing your changes to your remote repo, git will silently convert any consecutive 8-space strings it sees into tab characters. This can be highly undesirable, especially if you collaborate with a team that expects the code to be indented using spaces instead of tabs.

At the very least, the comment above this line should very clearly explain the fact that `indent-with-non-tab` does more than advertised in the [`git-config` man page](https://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/git-config.html).

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/330,26618946,MDU6SXNzdWUyNjYxODk0Ng==,330,Things set with PlistBuddy on Mavericks need a little extra push,3311113,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,4,2014-01-30T18:08:42Z,2014-02-04T15:36:39Z,2014-02-04T15:36:34Z,NONE,NA,On Mavericks, preferences are cached.  This means that any of the things you set in .osx using PlistBuddy will not work unless you also kill the user's instance of the `cfprefsd` daemon: `killall -u yourself cfprefsd`.

If you don’t do this, then either the changes will never take effect, or they must wait until something triggers the `cfprefsd` to reload what’s in the `.plist` files. This usually takes ages, and also sometimes is unreliable (sometimes the `.plist` file entries get rewritten with the cached values before the `cfprefsd` has had a chance to re-read the `.plist` file).

In the case of the PlistBuddy commands that change the `ViewSettings`, I found that if killing `cfprefsd` doesn’t happen very quickly after PlistBuddy makes the change, the changes will never get picked up.
Things set with the `defaults` command are not affected.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/273,21885705,MDU6SXNzdWUyMTg4NTcwNQ==,273,Override `ssh` to avoid sending multiple (incorrect) keys to each host,81942,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,4,2013-10-31T09:49:19Z,2013-11-02T07:06:41Z,2013-11-02T07:06:41Z,OWNER,NA,See http://serverfault.com/a/450807/13896 for some background.

The problem with `IdentityFile` is that it just adds the key to the list of keys to send to _each_ host — there’s no way to say “if and only if this is host X, send this key”. (To check which keys `ssh` is offering to the host, use the `-v` option.)
The `IdentitiesOnly yes` setting helps, but causes issues when `ssh`ing into a box for which there is no entry in `~/.ssh/config` yet, e.g. `ssh foo@example.com`:
> Received disconnect from $IP: Too many authentication failures for $user
What I’d like is for `ssh someknownhost` to connect to `someknownhost` using the key (`IdentityFile`) I specified for that host in `~/.ssh/config`.
On the other hand, `ssh foo@example.com` (i.e. `ssh` followed by a host that is not listed in `~/.ssh/config`) should not send any of my keys, as if the `-o PubkeyAuthentication=no` option was used.

So, I’d like to override `ssh` with a function that automatically adds `-o PubkeyAuthentication=no` to the command unless there is a _known host_ in the argument list. Known hosts are defined as `hosts=""$(grep ""^Host"" ~/.ssh/config | grep -v ""[?*]"" | cut -d "" "" -f2 | tr ' ' '\n')""`.

FWIW, @janmoesen did something similar here: https://gist.github.com/janmoesen/7114384 This solution requires hardcoding the host/key mappings, though. Adding `-o PubkeyAuthentication=no` when needed seems simpler.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/237,18725290,MDU6SXNzdWUxODcyNTI5MA==,237,.osx: Consider updating L88--90 comment about Adobe apps,2207980,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2013-08-29T11:27:37Z,2017-03-07T05:31:47Z,2017-03-07T05:31:47Z,NONE,NA,Hi there! First off, standard enthusiastic thanks for your work maintaining this repository. I come back to .osx constantly when I have a new machine or OS to set up, and I'm slowly exploring the others. Terrific stuff.

I have one tiny contribution to make to the whole enterprise: I thought it might be worth noting on [lines 88--90 of `.osx`](https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/blob/bd9429af1cfdc7f4caa73e6f98773ed69a161c9c/.osx#L88-L91) that the `~/.CFUserTextEncoding` thing also breaks Adobe Creative Cloud apps---like all of them, the whole kit and caboodle, even things versioned way after CS5. Based on some aggressive Googling and forum-trawling, I think it's just me and one or two other UTF-loving folks who've experienced the lethal configuration combination, but when it happens, there's nothing in the crash logs or the diagnostics or in heaven or in hell to indicate why no Creative Cloud app, not even the installers, will load. I happened to stumble across a since-lost post where someone figured it out, and as soon as I deleted my `~/.CFUserTextEncoding` file and rebooted I was able to run everything just fine.
Thanks again for a great resource!

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/234,17771322,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NzQ1ODE3Mw==,234,Add a slash to directories when listing,506129,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2013-08-07T20:17:06Z,2014-06-24T02:13:58Z,2013-08-08T08:41:20Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,Having a slash after a directory name is yelling _DIRECTORY_ for decades.
That's why I really like the `-F` flag.
It has other useful features as well.

> Display a slash (`/`) immediately after each pathname that is a directory, an asterisk (`*`) after each that is executable, an at sign (`@`) after each symbolic link, an equals sign (`=`) after each socket, a percent sign (`%`) after each whiteout, and a vertical bar (`|`) after each that is a FIFO.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/233,17658939,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NzM5ODQ5MA==,233,Install hub via brew and alias g to hub,506129,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,3,2013-08-05T20:50:30Z,2014-06-13T00:32:14Z,2014-06-11T11:10:15Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,## [Hub](https://github.com/github/hub) is a great way to work with GitHub!
- Use `user/repo` syntax everywhere to refer to GitHub URLs.
- Work with multiple remotes for upstream and origin.
It is great for both open-source contributors and maintainers.
See the different workflows here: http://hub.github.com/
**Yes, it is created and maintained by GitHub!**
It is recommended to alias `git` to `hub`, because it also enhances existing commands like `apply`, `am`, `clone`, `fetch` and others.
I am aliasing `g` to `hub` so when you type you will use `hub`, but other tools which use `git` will not interfere with `hub` abilities.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/206,14593148,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NTg0Njg1OQ==,206,bootstrap.sh bug: if bootstrap pulls a new bootstrap, syncing continues with old bootstrap -> bad things happen",1893345,open,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2013-05-21T21:43:58Z,2020-06-16T07:07:19Z,NA,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,"Previously, if bootstrap.sh had been changed in the origin repo,
the syncing would continue using the old bootstrap.sh. This can
cause problems such as the following: Say you have added a new
LICENSE file and an appropriate exclusion in the rsync of bootstraph.sh.
When a user does `source bootstrap.sh` the new LICENSE file and
bootstrap.sh file get pulled but the syncing continues with the old
bootstrap which doesn't have the exclusion, thus giving you a LICENSE
file in your ~. This commit gives a basic solution of exiting if the
bootstrap.sh file has changed after the `git pull`.
> Ideally, this could be automated because there isn't any real reason the user should be bothered. I just wasn't sure how to implement it.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/199,13764906,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NTQyNjQ4NA==,199,.functions: Improve `targz`,81942,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2013-04-29T15:12:53Z,2014-06-26T02:44:01Z,2013-05-01T14:04:19Z,OWNER,NA,Idea: Would be cool if `targz foo` would create `foo.tar`, then check its file size, and then use it to decide wether to use `zopfli` or `gzip`. Anything over, say, 50 MB, should probably use gzip. Zopfli is great for small files, but quickly becomes too slow as file size increases.
@alrra suggested using fewer Zopfli iterations (`15` is the default) but I’m not sure about that, as it would minimize the benefit of using Zopfli.
@einars suggested using [pigz](http://zlib.net/pigz/) (`brew install pigz`), the fast gzip-compatible multithreaded compressor™. Perhaps another check before falling back to `gzip`?

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/167,9899316,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MzY0OTE2Nw==,167,Google drive git,10137,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,0,2013-01-12T00:01:15Z,2014-07-10T16:01:02Z,2013-02-07T01:09:45Z,NONE,NA,A few tools to automate the initialization and cloning of Google Drive hosted git repos
This allows to easily share private git repositories or just to backup your own work.

Type `git init-gd` in a directory to create a initialize a local git repo and create a ""remote"" origin bare git repo in your local  google drive folder (under git/current-directory-name/). You can then directly push and pull to this remote repo.
Using a git url shortcut, you can type `git clone gd:my-repo` to clone a repo from your google drive.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/165,9831254,MDU6SXNzdWU5ODMxMjU0,165,.bashrc vs .bash_profile,1271434,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,3,2013-01-10T04:38:04Z,2015-07-17T06:44:23Z,2015-07-17T06:44:23Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,I'm seeing conflicting advice on this.
States the bash manual and best practice is to have .bash_profile link to .bashrc, not the other way around.
- correctly detects `SDCH` compression according to the [specification](http://www.blogs.zeenor.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/Shared_Dictionary_Compression_over_HTTP.pdf)
- correctly overwrites the user agent (using the -A, not the -H option)
- limits the connection and operation time (this is useful for preventing the function from hanging for hours due to slow networks or links going down)
**Tested on:** Mac OS X v.10.8.2 and Ubuntu 12.04 LTS

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/159,9016702,MDU6SXNzdWU5MDE2NzAy,159,bootstrap.sh makes your $HOME public,1105174,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,6,2012-12-05T11:53:03Z,2013-05-01T14:10:16Z,2013-05-01T14:09:33Z,NONE,NA,The README instructs you to do the following:
git clone https://github.com/mathiasbynens/dotfiles.git && cd dotfiles && source bootstrap.sh
Cloning the repo without setting a umask actually creates a `dotfiles` directory whose permissions reflect the current umask, in most cases leading to a world-readable directory:
No problem until here. But then `bootstrap.sh` does the following:

... which does not sync the directory's _content_ but the directory _itself_, including its permissions. After that, if `dotfiles` has been publically readable, `$HOME` is too, which really is unacceptable on a multi-user system.

Any Linux distro that I personally know (quite a couple) uses 002 or 022 as the default umask while `useradd` creates the home directory of a user with 007 or 077 as configured in `/etc/login.defs`, so on most systems the default installation process will lead to a privacy incident.

Please advise users that want to install your dotfiles to set an adequate umask before. Getting the permissions of their home directory incidently changed (without notice!) is quite surprising, and in many cases, dangerous.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/126,6423140,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjE0OTA2Ng==,126,Fixed 'flush' alias to work with OSX 10.7 & 10.8,590520,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,1,2012-08-24T00:12:29Z,2014-07-10T16:15:44Z,2012-08-24T14:38:06Z,CONTRIBUTOR,NA,The 'flush' alias is out-of-date. Starting in OS X Lion (10.7), it is necessary not only to use the old `dscacheutil -flushcache`, but also to use `killall -HUP mDNSResponder`. Apple explains this change in [this support article](http://support.apple.com/kb/HT5343). This change applies to Mountain Lion (10.8) as well as Lion.
- Previous `fs` didn’t show total sizes of directories—this `fs` does that.
- If no argument specified, new `fs` will list all files inside the current directory, including hidden files.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/92,5852924,MDU6SXNzdWU1ODUyOTI0,92,.osx: Remove delay when dragging icons from the Dock to remove them,81942,open,FALSE,NA,NA,3,2012-07-26T12:58:09Z,2013-03-07T21:37:50Z,NA,OWNER,NA,As you all know, Dock icons can be removed by simply clicking them and dragging them out of the Dock. As soon as the “poof” animation appears, you can release the mouse button to remove the icon.

It seems like in Mountain Lion there is a bit of a delay plus a minimum distance required between when you start dragging and when the “poof” animation appears, i.e. when you can release the mouse button to remove the icon. If you release the mouse button before the “poof” animation appears, the icon won’t be deleted from the Dock. If you don’t drag the icon far enough away from the Dock, the “poof” animation won’t appear at all, and again the icon won’t be deleted from the Dock when you release the mouse button.
Is there a hidden setting (`defaults write`-style) or some other way to disable this delay and/or minimum distance setting?
Based on this output, I’d expect the following to work:
Ideas on how to get this to work are welcome!

I have tested this in one of my projects and indeed, it works like a charm! This is what I have wanted for some years now.
I have kept `modeline` support as it is opt-in and I have a few individual files that use it at the moment. Leaving it for @mathiasbynens to decide whether `modeline` support should stay in there.
This feature is very useful for enforcing consistent whitespacing (tab vs space), indenting (4 vs 2 spaces) and many others.

By enabling this setting, users can opt into modeline by commenting their files. If vim does not detect anything in the first 4 lines of any file, it will simply ignore and use default settings as specificed by the .vimrc file.

mathiasbynens,dotfiles,https://api.github.com/repos/mathiasbynens/dotfiles/issues/58,4307000,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTI0MDM4MQ==,58,Scripts to backup and restore settings modified by .osx,156303,closed,FALSE,NA,NA,2,2012-04-26T16:50:05Z,2014-06-13T17:33:45Z,2012-11-24T08:47:27Z,NONE,NA,I noticed quite a few people were worried about permanently losing the OS defaults, so I created a couple of scripts to backup and then restore the settings.
The backup script `osx_backup.sh` needs to be run before `.osx`. This could potentially be called from `.osx` automatically.
The settings are backed up to a text file `.osx_settings_backup` in the format `<setting> : <value>`. This file I've added to the ignores.
The restore script `osx_restore.sh` uses the backup file to restore all the settings.
I've been using both scripts with success on a couple of machines. Not a problem if you think it's overkill, but it might come in handy for a few people. Let me know what you think.
